Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Electrochemical Reduction of CO2 to Small Organic Fuels on Encapsulated Metal Catalysts in Gas Diffusion Electrode Environment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Li, Wenzhen / Williams, Christopher
Proposal Number: 1235982 / 1235654
Institution: Michigan Technological University / University of South Carolina at Columbia
Title: Collaborative Research: Electrochemical Reduction of CO2 to Small Organic Fuels on Encapsulated Metal Catalysts in Gas Diffusion Electrode Environment

The increase of the greenhouse gas CO2 in the atmosphere has resulted in serious global warming issues. The electroreduction of CO2 to organic molecules is a critical goal that would positively impact the global carbon balance by recycling CO2 back into usable fuels. However, an electroreduction that is fast enough and can operate to full capacity remains a great scientific challenge.

This collaborative team proposes to investigate a novel class of carbon nanotube (CNT) encapsulated Cu-based nanostructures for efficient electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 in gas diffusion phase, based on their extensive research expertise in catalysis, spectroscopy and electrochemical engineering. The research hypotheses are: 1) that inside CNT channels, CO2 and H species transport and charge transfer can be effectively tuned through optimizing the diameter and length of CNTs and distribution of metal nanoparticles; 2) that the spatial restriction of CNT channels can enhance chain growth probability (to form C2+ fuels); 3) that the cation exchange ionomer can effectively adjust the local pH of reaction sites close to neutral in order to facilitate CO2 reduction. The project will focus on three research tasks: 1) rationally design, accurately synthesize and fully characterize CNTs encapsulated Cu- based bimetallic (Fe, Ag, Pd, etc) nanoparticles having alloy or core-shell structure; 2) investigate mechanistic steps of CO2 reduction at the encapsulated catalyst-cation exchange membrane ionomer interface using in-situ electrochemical FTIR, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry and high performance liquid chromatography; 3) assemble encapsulated catalysts into MEAs and investigate CO2 reduction in gas diffusion electrode environment using electrochemical methods, chromatography analysis, and micro-kinetic modeling.

This research will have several broad scientific and social impacts. First, studies of these novel encapsulated catalytic systems will advance knowledge of precise synthesis of composite catalytic materials and structure-catalytic function relationships. Second, the research efforts will deepen our understanding of electro-driven conversion of CO2 to usable organic fuels (electrofuels). Third, it will advance CO2 conversion knowledge based on solid polymer electrolyte and gas diffusion electrode techniques and support the world-wide research efforts to balance global carbon cycling and alleviate global climate change issues. The students involved will not only acquire hands-on research skills, but also learn analytical, communication, cooperation and innovation skills. In addition, the PIs will incorporate the generated results into the existing undergraduate courses and enterprise projects. The outreach efforts will increase high school students? interests in science, engineering and technology, and eventually benefit our society by a sustainably supply of new generation researchers in these fields.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research: Electrochemical Reduction of CO2 to Small Organic Fuels on Encapsulated Metal Catalysts in Gas Diffusion Electrode Environment (CBET-1235982. 09/1/2012-07/19/2014, CBET-1501113; 07/20/2014-08/31/2015, $174,567)

 

         This NSF project designed and prepared CNT and graphene supported Cu-based nanoparticle catalysts; explored CO2 electrocatalytic reduction in half electrochemical cells and studied electrochemical reduction of bionewable molecules containing carbonyl groups (e.g. levulinic acid) in flow electrochemical cells. New knowledge of synthesis of Cu, Ag and Au nanoparticles and new insights into electro-reduction of CO2 and organic molecule with carbonyl group have been generated. The acquired knowledge can be broadly applied to various areas, such as catalysis, water electrolysis, electrochemical reduction, electrochemical engineering, etc. The PI’s team actively worked on this project and the research activities/findings in the three years are: 1) Three solution phase synthesis methods to preparation of CNT or graphene supported Cu, Ag, and Au monometallic nanoparticles, and the Cu nanoparticle size was successfully controlled to <5 nm and uniformly deposition on carbon black, CNT and graphene supports. 2) Cu foil with a nanostructure surface (nanoparticle or nanorod) was developed with controlled thickness. 3) An advanced electrochemical test system, which can compensate the internal resistance and satisfy isothermal test, was developed for the electrochemical reduction research. 4) One H-type electrolysis cell and two electrolysis flow cells were designed for electrochemical reduction of CO2 and hydrogenation of biomass-compounds, respectively. 5) In collaboration with the electrochemistry group at Naval Research Lab (NRL), carbon supported Cu nanoparticles were prepared using a self-developed nanocapsule method, and was tested for electro-reduction of CO2. It was found that the 12 nm Cu/C can improve CO2 electro-reduction rate and facilitate the production of C2 ethylene. 6) Carbon supported small amorphous Ni-Fe nanoparticles was found to be a promising oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalyst, which can be coupled at the anode of an electrolysis cell for CO2 reduction at the cathode. 7) Electro-hydrogenation of levulinic acid (a biorenewable molecule containing ketone group) over Pb foil was investigated and possible hydrogenation mechanisms were provided. 8) Cu is also found to be a unique metal to deep reduction of furfural to methyl furan (4-electron-transfer), which is similar to that Cu is the unique metal to CO2/CO reduction to hydrocarbon products (methane or ethylene). With the support of this NSF grant, totally six research papers were published in peer-reviewed journals (ChemSusChem, Green Chemistry, Langmuir, Renewable Energy, ACS Catalysis), and five invited talks were given in universities, research institutes and workshops.

 

Our research activities have been closely integrated into a variety of education and outreach activities, and have greatly stimulated the passion of the participating students in sustainable energy, catalysis and electrochemistry research. Five graduate and two undergraduate students (three are female students) have actively participated in this research project and obtained strict energy and electrochemistry research training. An effective collaboration with DOD-NRL electrochemistry lab was established to investigate the particle size effect on electro-reduction of CO2 over Cu nanoparticle catalysts. The PI has integrated his research into an interd...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Collaborative Research: Electrochemical Reduction of CO2 to Small Organic Fuels on Encapsulated Metal Catalysts in Gas Diffusion Electrode Environment (CBET-1235982. 09/1/2012-07/19/2014, CBET-1501113; 07/20/2014-08/31/2015, $174,567) This NSF project designed and prepared CNT and graphene supported Cu-based nanoparticle catalysts; explored CO2 electrocatalytic reduction in half electrochemical cells and studied electrochemical reduction of bionewable molecules containing carbonyl groups (e.g. levulinic acid) in flow electrochemical cells. New knowledge of synthesis of Cu, Ag and Au nanoparticles and new insights into electro-reduction of CO2 and organic molecule with carbonyl group have been generated. The acquired knowledge can be broadly applied to various areas, such as catalysis, water electrolysis, electrochemical reduction, electrochemical engineering, etc. The PIÆs team actively worked on this project and the research activities/findings in the three years are: 1) Three solution phase synthesis methods to preparation of CNT or graphene supported Cu, Ag, and Au monometallic nanoparticles, and the Cu nanoparticle size was successfully controlled to <5 nm and uniformly deposition on carbon black, CNT and graphene supports. 2) Cu foil with a nanostructure surface (nanoparticle or nanorod) was developed with controlled thickness. 3) An advanced electrochemical test system, which can compensate the internal resistance and satisfy isothermal test, was developed for the electrochemical reduction research. 4) One H-type electrolysis cell and two electrolysis flow cells were designed for electrochemical reduction of CO2 and hydrogenation of biomass-compounds, respectively. 5) In collaboration with the electrochemistry group at Naval Research Lab (NRL), carbon supported Cu nanoparticles were prepared using a self-developed nanocapsule method, and was tested for electro-reduction of CO2. It was found that the 12 nm Cu/C can improve CO2 electro-reduction rate and facilitate the production of C2 ethylene. 6) Carbon supported small amorphous Ni-Fe nanoparticles was found to be a promising oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalyst, which can be coupled at the anode of an electrolysis cell for CO2 reduction at the cathode. 7) Electro-hydrogenation of levulinic acid (a biorenewable molecule containing ketone group) over Pb foil was investigated and possible hydrogenation mechanisms were provided. 8) Cu is also found to be a unique metal to deep reduction of furfural to methyl furan (4-electron-transfer), which is similar to that Cu is the unique metal to CO2/CO reduction to hydrocarbon products (methane or ethylene). With the support of this NSF grant, totally six research papers were published in peer-reviewed journals (ChemSusChem, Green Chemistry, Langmuir, Renewable Energy, ACS Catalysis), and five invited talks were given in universities, research institutes and workshops. Our research activities have been closely integrated into a variety of education and outreach activities, and have greatly stimulated the passion of the participating students in sustainable energy, catalysis and electrochemistry research. Five graduate and two undergraduate students (three are female students) have actively participated in this research project and obtained strict energy and electrochemistry research training. An effective collaboration with DOD-NRL electrochemistry lab was established to investigate the particle size effect on electro-reduction of CO2 over Cu nanoparticle catalysts. The PI has integrated his research into an interdisciplinary Fuel Cell Fundamental Class. The knowledge in electro-reduction of CO2 have been disseminated into the Alternative Energy Enterprise projects that were supervised by the PI at Michigan Tech. The PI has participated in Michigan TechÆs existing Summer Youth Programs and trained diverse high school students to learn catalyst preparation, electrode fabrication, electrolysis cell assembly a...
